item.title: Dharma
item.description: In buddhism, the Dharma is teaching of the Buddha. It is the core of the buddhist philosophy. I perceive the dharma as the sign posts helping the meditators on the path.

item.title: Equanimity
item.description: Equanimity is the quality of remaining calm, still, and at peace, in the face of extreme adversity and suffering. It is a quality that a meditator cultivates over hours of sitting on the cushion, training the mind to see the rise and fall of emotional waves, and then learning how to not give into them.

item.title: Impermanence
item.description: Impermanence is one of the core buddhist doctrines. It means that nothing last and everything fades away. Emotions, events, and thoughts are like waves, constantly rising and falling in our experiences.

item.title: The 3 jewels
item.description: In Buddhism, a meditator is invited to take refuge in the 3 jewels which are: The Dharma The Buddha The Sangha The Dharma is the theoretical map of the Path that each meditators explores on the way to awakening.

item.title: The Four Noble Truths
item.description: The Four Noble Truths is the heart of the Buddhist doctrine. It is not to be believed blindly, but rather, it is an invitation to try and see for oneself.

item.title: The Path
item.description: In Buddhism, the path is the name given to the journey of the meditators as they grow from novice to adapt.

item.title: Awakening
item.description: Awakening is a process where the mind ‘wakes up’ to the objective reality of its present experience. In buddhism, the end goal is awakening, also known as enlightenment.

item.title: The 8-fold path
item.description: The 8-fold path is the 4th noble truth in the The Four Noble Truths. It consists of 8 practices: Right view Right resolve Right speech Right conduct Right livelihood Right effort Right mindfulness Right concentration I struggled for a long time with the usage of the word Right, until I finally understood that it wasn’t about right or wrong in an absolute way.
